title: Break up monolithic dataWorker.worker.ts
description:
`src/workers/dataWorker.worker.ts` has swollen to ~1,650 lines and mixes unrelated responsibilities: global dataset state (lines 196-260), ingestion/load logic (495-870), filtering/sorting/search/grouping APIs (954-1290), and tag/fuzzy persistence (260-480). The single module mutates one giant `state` object from dozens of places, which makes it nearly impossible to reason about invariants, add tests, or reuse logic inside workers/tests. Even small changes risk regressions because everything is tightly coupled inside one file.

Tasks:
- [ ] Extract the dataset state machine (batch store, filter/sort state) into a dedicated module/class with a clear interface the worker can import.
- [ ] Move orthogonal features (load/parse, filtering, sorting, search, tagging persistence) into separate files so each area can be unit-tested independently and tree-shaken.
- [ ] Provide a thin worker entrypoint that wires these modules together and add targeted tests covering the extracted pieces (e.g., sorting, filter evaluation) without spinning up the whole worker.

title: Defer fuzzy index construction until after ingestion
description:
Every row parsed in `src/workers/csvParser.ts:366-369` immediately feeds `FuzzyIndexBuilder.addRow`, which tokenizes, normalizes, and updates trigram maps before we even finish loading the dataset. This work dominates CPU time for wide CSVs, yet the UI only needs the fuzzy index once the user runs a fuzzy search. We also block ingestion on persisting the snapshot (`dataWorker.worker.ts:558-620`), so users wait for two heavy passes before seeing data.

Tasks:
- [ ] Measure ingestion timelines with and without fuzzy building on realistic files to quantify the hit (rows/sec, time to first row rendered).
- [ ] Introduce a deferred mode where ingestion captures lightweight stats during parsing and kicks off fuzzy snapshot construction after the grid reaches `ready` (either in a background worker task or lazily when fuzzy search is invoked).
- [ ] Persist and hydrate the deferred snapshot the same way as today, but ensure the initial load resolves before fuzzy work completes.
- [ ] Add instrumentation/tests proving ingestion latency improves while fuzzy search continues to work once the snapshot job finishes.

Use tag store selectors in LabelsPanel and TagNotePanel
description:
Both `src/components/LabelsPanel.tsx:20` and `src/components/tagging/TagNotePanel.tsx:29` call `useTagStore()` with no selector, so React re-renders the panels for *every* tag-store change (any tag edit, status update, or label import). Because Zustand returns a new state object on each write, these heavy panels rerender even when they only need a couple of fields, making the label/tag modals noticeably janky while tags are streaming in.

Tasks:
- [ ] Replace the blanket `useTagStore()` calls with selector-based subscriptions (and `shallow` where helpful) so each component only re-renders when the specific pieces it uses actually change.
- [ ] Memoize callbacks derived from the store (e.g. `load`, `upsertLabel`, `deleteLabel`) or pull them via separate selectors to keep referential stability.
- [ ] Verify the dialogs no longer re-render when unrelated parts of the tag store change (e.g. editing another row's tag) and add a regression test if practical.

title: Stream column batches during CSV flush
description:
`src/workers/csvParser.ts:200-368` rebuilds every column on each batch flush by calling `rows.map(...)` for every header entry and then runs the type-specific encoders over those temporary arrays. For a 10k-row batch with 40 columns that means 400k string allocations (plus GC) before we even start writing typed data, effectively doubling the parser's work and memory footprint. This copy-heavy design is the main reason ingestion time explodes as column counts grow.

Tasks:
- [ ] Profile ingestion to capture how much time/memory is spent inside `buildColumnsFromRows()` for representative datasets (e.g. 10k×10, 10k×40, 100k×20).
- [ ] Replace the `rows` scratch arrays with streaming column builders that append values as we parse each row, so we only touch each value once before encoding.
- [ ] Ensure the new builders still feed the `TypeInferencer` and fuzzy hooks without requiring whole-row rereads.
- [ ] Update parser tests and add a regression benchmark that asserts rows/sec improved and memory stayed bounded.

title: Avoid double-copying row batches before OPFS writes
description:
`src/workers/rowBatchStore.ts:198-220` clones every typed array (`rowIds`, string offsets/data, null masks, etc.) into brand-new ArrayBuffers before calling `FileSystemWritableFileStream.write`. For large datasets this doubles memory traffic and adds a synchronous memcpy for each column, significantly extending ingestion time even though the underlying buffers are already contiguous. We only need to hand the writer the existing `ArrayBuffer`s (or views with byte offsets).

Tasks:
- [ ] Profile ingestion on a 1M-row CSV to measure how much time is spent inside `cloneArrayBuffer/cloneViewToArrayBuffer`.
- [ ] Update `storeBatch()` to stream the existing buffers (using `TypedArray` views or `ReadableStream`s) without materializing copies, while still keeping OPFS compatibility.
- [ ] Ensure memory fallback mode and null-mask handling still work without copies; add tests covering both.
- [ ] Document/benchmark the ingestion improvement after removing the redundant copies.

- [ ] Backfill unit tests for each module to cover error handling and data exchange with the state manager.

title: Add arrow key navigation
Prevent stale filter results from overwriting state
description:
`useFilterSync` dispatches async worker calls in `src/hooks/useFilterSync.ts:71-125` without any request tracking. If a user edits multiple predicates quickly, an earlier `worker.applyFilter()` promise can resolve after the latest change and clobber `setFilterSummary`, `setMatchedRowCount`, and `setFuzzyUsed` with stale counts. The UI will report the wrong matched-row total and may auto-enable fuzzy flags for predicates that were already deleted.

Tasks:
- [ ] Add a request sequence/token (e.g. `useRef`) so only the most recent applyFilters invocation updates the stores.
- [ ] Ensure we clear summaries/search results only when the current filters match the response to avoid staleness.
- [ ] Cover the race with a unit test for `useFilterSync` (mocking the worker) to prove earlier promises no longer overwrite newer state.

comments.author: nbareil
comments.text:
Implementation plan:
1. Update src/hooks/useFilterSync.ts to track an incrementing requestId via useRef so we can ignore stale worker responses. Store the latest requestId before calling applyFilter and bail out if a resolving promise is older than the most recent invocation.
2. When expressions are null (clearing filters) ensure the same request gating logic applies so clearFilterSummary/matched row updates only run for the active request.
3. Extend src/hooks/useFilterSync.test.tsx with a scenario that fires two applyFilters calls, resolves the second before the first, and asserts the store state reflects only the latest response. Mock the worker to control the promise resolution order.
